 - 1 - 1. MONGOLIA'S URBAN SERVICES SECTOR A. MONGOLIA: A COUNTRY IN ECONOMIC TRANSITION 1.1 Mongolia, landlocked between Russia and China, is a relatively poor country, with a per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of only about $440 in 1996. Compared with many other low-income countries, Mongolia's economy is relatively well diversified, with agriculture-primarily livestock-accounting for about 20 percent of GDP; industry-principally mining and wool, cashmere, leather and food processing- for 45 percent of GDP; and the services sectors, including a large government sector, a weak banking system and a growing private wholesale and retail trading sector, accounting for the balance. 1.2 Mongolia is among the world's most sparsely-populated countries (1.46 per km2), with an area of some 1.6 million km2-half the size of India-and a population of only 2.32 million people. About a quarter of the population are nomadic herders whose livestock outnumber the human population 11 to 1. Land, although relatively abundant, has limited productivity and a short growing season because of the country's harsh, semiarid continental climate and relatively high altitude. Besides sizable reserves of copper and other minerals, Mongolia has a potential for petroleum production in commercial quantities. The population is well educated, with an adult literacy rate of 96 percent and a sizable skilled labor force. Until 1990 and the end of its 70 years as a centrally planned economy, Mongolia benefited from substantial grant financial assistance (estimated at 30 percent of GDP annually) and managerial assistance from the former Soviet Union (FSU). 1.3 With the collapse of the Soviet Union, the attendant sudden withdrawal of its aid, and the collapse of demand from traditional Soviet-bloc trading partners who accounted for 95 percent of its exports, Mongolia suffered a massive economic shock. Real GDP fell by 20 percent during 1990-93, causing a sharp deterioration in both the external payment position and the Government's fiscal position. The Government responded with an austerity program characterized by gradual liberalization toward a market economy, including price decontrol and privatization. In 1992-93, small enterprises and livestock ownership were rapidly privatized, and by end-1994, the assets of about 1,200 large public enterprises were privatized, although the remaining 200 public enterprises still to be reformed account for over 30 percent of employment and value added in the economy. 1.4 At the same time, hyperinflation forced severe government cutbacks, causing delivery of social services to plummet and with them, social conditions: school attendance dropped 30 percent, maternal mortality doubled, the real value of pensions fell by 60 percent, wages nearly halved, and an estimated 30 percent of the population still
 - 2 - live below the poverty line. During this period, the Association assisted the Government with foreign exchange support for critical imports, technical assistance in key macroeconomic and sectoral areas and investments and technical assistance to begin rehabilitating the transportation system. In 1996, a poverty assessment study (Report No. 15723-MOG) was backed up by projects to alleviate the effects of the economic transition on the poor or vulnerable, and to rehabilitate a major coal mine. 1.5 By the end of 1996, the economy appeared to have weathered the worst of the shocks, but is still fragile. After suffering negative growth during 1991-93, GDP grew by 2.5 percent in 1994 and 6.3 percent in 1995. But with a 33 percent decline in copper prices and 10 percent drop in cashmere export prices, growth in the first half of 1996 fell to less than 1 percent. Although major macroeconomic targets agreed with external lenders are being met, the pace of reform slowed in 1995-96, and the challenges for the policymakers remain daunting. Mongolia's leaders must: continue and deepen structural reform; maintain satisfactory levels of income; reduce the poverty level; improve the welfare of pensioners; and reduce inflation. Though down from its 1993 high of about 325 percent, inflation was still about 50 to 60 percent in 1995/96, primarily due to loose monetary and fiscal policies, excessive bank and government credit creation, weak budget revenue generation and defaults on debt payments by state enterprises. Two recently approved IDA projects aimed at banking and enterprise reform should help with some of these problems. 1.6 Mongolia's new national government, elected in mid-1996, has announced a wide-ranging, accelerated reform agenda. The major objectives are to: (a) speed up company privatization; (b) reduce tax burdens on producers by 30 percent; (c) improve tax administration and broaden the tax base; (d) promote foreign investment; (e) improve foreign assistance coordination; (f) refocus social security on the most needy; (g) reduce govermnent expenditure and, to achieve better governance, prepare a code of ethics for all government members. 1.7 By end-1996, the Government had already implemented some courageous sectoral and macroeconomic reforms conforming with the goals outlined above. These included: (a) raising electricity and heating tariffs by 60 percent; coal prices by 45 percent and petroleum prices by 29 to 60 percent; (b) abolishing price commissions that were controlling prices of basic commodities in major urban centers; (c) enacting new laws on central and commercial banking operations; and (d) reducing the number of ministries and departments from 16 to 9. B. THE URBAN SETTING Urbanization in Mongolia 1.8 Of the national population of 2.32 million in 1995, about 55 percent were urban. Overall population growth in the 1990s has been about 2 percent a year, while urban growth averaged only 1 percent but was concentrated in the three largest cities, as smaller rural centers declined. Political and economic changes in the 1990s are believed to have
 - 3 - caused increased migration to the larger urban areas at the expense of the smaller towns. Currently, about a quarter of the population or an estimated 620,000 people lives in the capital city of Ulaanbaatar (UB), and another 25 percent lives in other urban centers, including the three next largest cities-Darhan with 91,300, Erdenet with 62,900 and Choibalsan with 46,400. Except for those living in the capitals of the country's 17 aimags or provinces, averaging 20,300 each, most other people live in widely dispersed, and much smaller, urban centers, essentially large villages. Urban Services Delivery 1.9 Mongolia's cities bear the imprint of socialist urban planning, that is, a reliance on rigid physical norms with little regard to user demand, technological alternatives, or realistic resource constraints. The upshot of these policies has been lopsided urban development. The combination of high standards for publicly-financed formal housing and urban services and inadequate resources to provide such housing and services to all city residents stranded a large segment of the urban population in self-financed housing in plotted developments, where standards of facilities and services are much lower than those in the formal housing areas. The traditional housing areas, known as ger areas, comprise individually fenced plots and clusters of traditional round tents (gers)1 and/or assorted low-cost structures ranging from wooden shacks to a scattering of two-story brick houses. 1.10 Ger Area Services. Due to their supposedly temporary nature, the ger areas have received the bare minimum of infrastructure investment, usually only individual electricity connections and communal water collection points. The ger areas lack other basic services, such as paved, or at least stabilized access roads, community services, piped water supply and sanitation. Pit latrines are universal, and coal, wood or dung-fired stoves are used for heating and cooking. There are generally few communal social facilities. Local governments lay out and allot the individual plots to residents, with an occupation right of unspecified duration. Whereas industries and apartments generally lie within the serviced areas, most ger housing areas fall outside the piped water and sewerage systems. Instead, ger residents must rely on water expensively trucked to and sold from public water kiosks. And, while apartment residents obtain almost all their services from public entities at highly subsidized prices, most services in the ger are charged at full cost. This continues to hold true even though the ger areas house the largest part of the urban poor, who constitute about 46 percent of the ger population. The average income of ger households varies by location, but is estimated to be about $65 equivalent, or about 70 percent of average household income in the formal serviced areas. 1.11 In recent years, ger areas have tended to develop without control, because newcomers generally identify a plot first and only afterward regularize occupancy with I Ger tents have light, demountable wooden frame construction covered by several layers of felt and canvas.
 - 4 - the local government administration. This results in occupancy of land unsuited for residential use and difficult or expensive to provide with infrastructure or services. Such is the case with gers situated on steep slopes, near hilltops above the reach of water supply reservoirs, and in areas subject to flooding. In the future, the local authorities will need to enforce controls on new settlement and clearly indicate the land open to new settlement. The low density of the ger areas (at 10 plots/hectare-ha) and their spread over an increasing area cannot continue as this also makes delivery of urban services difficult and expensive. In this regard, the proposed project would include a study of ger development planning in UB. 1.12 Urban Services in the Formal Housing Sector. With the important exception of the ger areas, Mongolia has a reasonable-but possibly unaffordable-level of urban services, mostly built over the past 20 years. * Over 100 piped water systems are operated in all centers, generally from deep wells. These systems, augmented by tankered water outside the distribution systems, serve about 81 percent of the urban population. * Major cities, two provincial centers and large towns are served by sewerage systems and associated sewage treatment. Water and sewerage and other services are handled by the same unit-whether a municipal company in cities or a municipal department in large towns. * Solid waste management is handled by the local governments. All urban centers are served with some type of solid waste collection system. 1.13 Service Quality. The quality of the urban services provided has deteriorated badly, in part because of the economic retrenchment and deep cuts in government spending for maintenance. Since 1990, most capital investment and expansion projects have been halted, and even minor repairs of existing assets has been severely curtailed. In general, the formal utility services face severe equipment problems. All equipment originated from FSU countries and is now difficult to replace or maintain with spares because of the severance of relationships with previous suppliers and inadequate hard currency to pay for imports. For instance, more than 10 percent of the wells in the well fields supplying UB are inoperative due to faulty pumps; the municipal sewage plant treats only 75 percent of the sewage due to defective pumps and equipment; and pipe breaks take three to four days to repair due to lack of materials and equipment. 1.14 Low levels of cost recovery, typical of the Soviet era when users contributed little and utilities received substantial subsidies for new investments, have exacerbated service delivery problems. Metering-whether of water, heat, or power-on apartment blocks or individual premises is almost nonexistent. Water and sewerage are billed on the basis of low assumed consumption norms, and collection of bills may be as low as 50 percent in the aimags and 80 percent in UB. While tariff levels cover full costs of the present low level of operations and depreciation, they are insufficient to cover the costs of adequate
 - D - levels of maintenance and rehabilitation, much less new investments in the systems. Recovery of solid wastes service costs is limited and has led to deteriorating and unsatisfactory collection and disposal services. Solid waste is disposed to sites operated as open dumps, accepting mixed industrial, institutional and domestic wastes, and having no environmental controls. The lack of funds has also affected the staff working in the sector, who have not benefited from training in efficient operational procedures. 1.15 The lack of maintenance and the overall deterioration in standards have also had environmental repercussions. Industrial sewage is being discharged directly to rivers, and aquifers used for cities' water supply are beginning to show pollution from heavy metals and high concentrations of chemical oxygen demand. The Government's (draft) National Environmental Action Plan places high priority on addressing these problems. Unless urgent remedial steps are taken, the cost of restoring reliable urban services and a sustainable environment is likely to rise sharply. C. SECTOR INSTITUTIONS Ministry of Infrastructure Development 1.16 The Ministry of Infrastructure Development (MID) has been responsible for public services policy since 1994. MID has broad responsibilities, ranging from tourism to coal mining and including the Department of Urban Development, Housing and Public Utilities. The latter is responsible for: (a) formulating urban development policies; (b) preparing the legal framework for urban development, housing, public services; management coordination and inspection; (c) planning the funding of public services, and (d) managing design and research and provision of government expertise. Reflecting the importance now being given to municipal services by Mongolia's new National government, in January 1997 a formerly semiautonomous government company, the State Concern for Municipal Utilities, was absorbed in MID and renamed the Urban Services Agency. Public utility companies in the provincial (aimag) centers and the water supply and sewerage company in UB have to date been only nominally coordinated by the Ministry; real responsibility rested with the local municipalities and aimag governors. D. GOVERNMENT SECTOR STRATEGY 1.17 After little action on the urban front since 1991 due to the economic crisis, the Government's sector policies are being reinvigorated with a market orientation. In December 1996, Parliament approved important Directives for the Economic and Social Development of Mongolia, providing for (a) the drafting of a law on a real estate tax, (b) implementation of land ownership measures and procedures, (c) an inventory and evaluation of state-owned fixed assets, including property, (d) development of a housing program, with new standards, and the resolution of problems relating to the financing of private housing, and (e) renovation of water supply and sewerage facilities in cities and settlements and improvement in their maintenance and levels of service. A Government plan also exists to concentrate settlement and national infrastructure development around
 five regional growth poles (including UB), supported by transport, communications and energy corridors. 1.18 The new development policy is consistent with a draft statement of Mongolia's urban development policy in its Medium-Term Strategy. The Strategy recognizes the need for: (a) private sector and individual initiatives, not the Government, in replacing ger housing; (b) better public provision of water supply and sanitation to the urban population to improve productivity and quality of life and to reduce poverty; and (c) cost recovery for the infrastructure services provided. The policy action matrix included in the Strategy, similar to some of the goals of the proposed IDA project, would: (a) provide water supply services to ger areas around UB; (b) establish effective demand management (pricing) mechanisms that reflect the scarcity value of water resources; and (c) improve sector planning in peri-urban areas. While resource limitations-both financial and human-may temper the implementation of the Strategy, the Government seems prepared to expand the reforms already introduced in other areas of the economy to the water supply sector. To this end, it is exploring ways to enhance its operational and financial efficiencies while mitigating the inequality between ger areas and the apartment sector. The proposed project would support both goals. E. RATIONALE FOR IDA INVOLVEMENT IN THE PROPOSED PROJECT 1.19 The proposed project supports three major goals of the Bank Group's June 1995 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), i.e., to protect the poor and other groups vulnerable to the effects of the country's economic transition, improve economic infrastructure, and promote a commercial orientation in local public enterprises. By delivering water supply and other urban services to predominantly poor ger areas in UB, the project supports both the Bank Group's objective of poverty alleviation in the country, and the Government's own Poverty Alleviation Program launched in 1994 to reduce the proportion of the population living below the poverty line and ease the social burden of structural reforms introduced during the transition to a market economy. By improving UB's water distribution network to benefit ger, apartment and other areas, the project responds to immediate urban infrastructure requirements that have gone unmet due to severe funding shortages. Project assistance for development and corporatization of UB's water supply and sewerage utility is expected to strengthen the economic and financial management of the system and facilitate the utility's development as a fully commercial entity. The project would also introduce market-oriented provisions for, and management of, urban services by providing better cost-recovery mechanisms as well as financial incentives for water conservation and operational efficiency. 1.20 The project directly supports the Government's recently announced sector strategy (para. 1.17) and complements other IDA-funded initiatives in Mongolia as well as those financed by other donors. It builds on recommendations of IDA's 1994 informal sector review, carried out as part of project identification, findings of the 1996 Mongolia Poverty Assessment (Report No. 15723-MOG) and the Poverty Alleviation for Vulnerable Groups Project (Cr. 2760-MN) now assisting the unemployed, disabled and

In its goal of reducing water losses in UB, it complements a proposed similar operation in the power sector to reduce energy losses in the capital. Project initiatives also share goals of similar work being done by other multi- and bilateral agencies, particularly the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA). All three are funding small water supply, sanitation and ger area improvement schemes in other areas of the country, and JICA is supporting UB's rehabilitation of water supply facilities; it also supports preparation of a drainage master plan for UB and, in future, is expected to finance priority works under the plan. F. LESSONS LEARNED FROM PREVIOUS PROJECTS 1.21 The Association has assisted Mongolia with three projects providing balance of payments or technical assistance support, two for structural adjustment of the banking and enterprise sectors, two for rehabilitation of the transport system and of the Baganuur coal mine near UB, and one for protection of vulnerable groups during this difficult period. The principal lesson leamed from these operations is the lack of local familiarity with basic project activities like procurement and disbursement, which can result in significant project startup delays and slower-than-expected progress thereafter. AusAID- funded assistance for preparation of the project, therefore, included preparation of major procurement packages for the first two project years. A four-member project management team of intemational consultants would also assist the Project Management Unit during the first 18 to 24 months of implementation. Such assistance should accelerate project startup and build local capabilities. In addition, counterpart funding constraints experienced under the Transport Rehabilitation Project (Cr. 2615, approved in May 1994), due to the imposition during implementation of import duties and sales tax on project inputs, would be avoided by including these taxes in the project cost estimate and budgetary planning by the Central and Municipal Govermnent to provide the full local funding requirement. 1.22 Experience gained outside of Mongolia has also influenced Project design. In a review of urban projects in the past 20 years, the Operations Evaluation Department's report "Twenty Years of Lending for Urban Development" stresses the importance of: (a) ensuring ownership of the project through participation of beneficiaries from the early stages to improve project design and reveal effective demand; (b) enhancing service delivery efficiency in a sustainable way through cost recovery, based on effective demand; and (c) making more efficient use of the existing infrastructure before developing additional networks, as part of the borrower's clear understanding of investment priorities. 1.23 The proposed project incorporates these lessons. First, to ensure project ownership, ger area leaders and representatives discussed their needs with the project preparation team during several stages of the preparation process. And, to prepare
 - 8 - stakeholders to assume responsibility for management and financial reforms under the project's institutional development component, during project preparation key utility managers and staff participated in a study tour of major utilities being successfully operated on commercial principles in neighboring countries. The positive feedback from the latter exercise should strengthen commitments to the project's reform agenda. Second, efficiency gains and cost recovery are key aims of the project's institutional and financial development activities. Third, the project is posited on maximizing the use of existing facilities rather than constructing new ones. Proposed water supply system investments would utilize existing underused reservoirs to reduce water supply costs, while the project's provision of some 13,000 water meters would enhance water conservation, reduce water supply costs, and alleviate the need for new system expansion during the next five years. Finally, project improvements in the ger areas will have accompanying environmental benefits due to improved sanitation and solid waste collection facilities.

ULAANBAATAR: How IT HAS DEVELOPED 2.1 Ulaanbaatar, with about 620,000 people in 1995 or 27 percent of the national population, is Mongolia's capital and the country's foremost city, having 42 percent of commercial activity, 50 percent of housing and 52 percent of investment activity. Since about 1970, its population has doubled, having grown at an annual average 6.8 percent in the 1970s, at more modest rates in the 1980s, and at about 2 percent in the 1990s. UB comprises six contiguous districts (duureg) and two districts enclaved in the adjoining province-the mining town of Baganuur about 100 km away and a former military base south of the city. While UB officially encompasses a total area of some 354,300 ha, the built-up areas account for only 20,000 ha. The site of the present city, lying between the Tuul River flood plain and the Khentii mountains, has been inhabited since ancient times. 2.2 In the 1950s, the Government promoted development of the industrial power stations in the UB region, demolished much of the traditional settlements in the central city area and erected apartment blocks in their place to house the inhabitants, together with a skilled work force from Russia. The city plan prepared at that time, and its subsequent modifications, envisaged the construction of a modem city of functionally distinct zones, large-scale infrastructure and rented housing of four- to eight-story apartment blocks. From the 1950s through the 1980s, this plan was substantially implemented using the Government's control of production, construction, employment and population movement. However, since the democratic reforms, these controls have been loosened, costs and prices have risen, but unemployment has sharply increased and for most people, real income has dropped. Due to these factors and to privatization of industries, Government revenues have declined, as has its ability to limit in-migration or maintain the pace of infrastructure construction to accommodate the rising growth of population and small-scale enterprises. 2.3 Due to these economic and political changes, apartment building has now almost stopped, and the majority of urban growth is in the ger areas surrounding the core "apartment city." The future of Ulaanbaatar seems to be in "ger development," gers being, in effect, low-cost suburban settlements. Families wishing to obtain a plot apply to the local khoroo (the smallest level of the city administration) and are allocated a 300 m or 500 m2 lot located and staked out by a survey from the city. Most new residents obtain land in this way, although there is an increasingly active real estate market. Only 10 percent of the plots are occupied by unregistered squatters. The government-owned land and the region's semidesert, uncultivated landscape allow rapid expansion of ger development with few legal or natural constraints.
 - 10- 2.4 The individual plots are laid out in simple rectangular blocks with wide public rights-of-way between plots. The plot-holders construct wooden fences around their plots, then erect the ger tent, possibly a conventional wood frame permanent building, and a pit privy toilet. Between one and four families may live on this plot, and one or more of the families may periodically move to herd livestock in rural areas, then return to their urban ger. Many families keep livestock on their plots or on the hills nearby. Livestock forms a significant part of household incomes, especially since the reduction of secure formal employment. 2.5 Socioeconomic surveys of ger residents in UB indicate that, although household incomes are low (median income is $76 month for an average size household of 4.8), income distribution is still fairly even (a positive legacy from the Communist period), although it is gradually becoming more skewed as the market economy takes hold. 2.6 Despite the economic problems, UB has a number of advantages over other capital cities in the developing world. It is not yet too large to be unmanageable. There is no widespread squatting, and the settlement process is fairly orderly. Settlement densities are fairly low, allowing scope to introduce services, and ger plot sites are large enough to permit incremental housing development and for residents to obtain a valuable future real estate asset. Distribution of income and assets (including urban land) is, as yet, fairly equal, and social divisions (regional, ethnic, religious) are insignificant. Literacy and education levels are high, potentially allowing informed dialogue and participation in issues of urban planning, management and development. B. URBAN SERVICE PROVISION IN MODERN AND TRADITIONAL HOUSING AREAS 2.7 The Modern Sector. About 55 percent of UB's population lives in fully-serviced public housing estates, comprised of 3- to 12-story apartment buildings in prefabricated modular construction. The housing estates, clustered near the city center and along the city's main roads, are relatively well-served by public transport. The apartments have cold and hot water, toilets and bathrooms, conventional piped sewage collection, on-site and off-site piped stormwater drainage, electricity, water heating, elevators in higher buildings and solid waste collection from apartment chutes. USAG, the municipal water supply and sewerage company, provides cold water to the housing sites; and hot water is generated in community heating centers on the housing sites. Apartment rents and utility charges have until recently been heavily subsidized. 2.8 Ger Areas. The remainder of the population or some 250,000 to 270,000 people live in 18 ger areas that sprawl mainly over the outlying hills and valleys to the north, northwest and northeast of UB, several kilometers from the city's economic activity. Densities in these areas are low, primarily due to the large plot sizes and the sporadic distribution of ger settlements. At these low densities, the cost of servicing ger areas is high, especially for roads and water supply. While the proposed project would extend piped water supply to public water kiosks in ger areas, individual household connections are currently unaffordable to most families. A greater problem exists when ger plots are
 - 11 - extended higher than the existing water reservoirs (the highest being 1,470 m). Above this level, the current pressure in the water system cannot service kiosks in the areas. 2.9 The higher cost of providing municipal services to the ger areas does not explain the minimal level of services there, which contrast sharply with the European-style, middle-income standard of the apartments. Ger services are generally as follows: * excreta are generally disposed to pit latrines, and sullage to the ground and natural drainage channels; * access is via rough, poorly-bridged earth roads. The wide rights-of-way are often eroded by stormwater flows; * there is virtually no formal stormwater drainage system; * solid waste is sporadically collected from bins at the end of residential lanes by local municipal workers; - high heating costs, in individual private wood or coal stoves, can consume about 10 percent of average household expenditure; - housing is solely by private household investment and, to be affordable to low ger incomes, is mostly in poorly-insulated wooden shacks or the traditional nomadic tent-the ger; - water is supplied from neighborhood kiosks filled by public tanker trucks; 3 some schools have been built but virtually no community centers, health clinics, or recreation areas. Pipe trench depths are generally between 2 and 3 m, in order to avoid freezing in UB's cold winters when average daily temperatures range from -13 to -25Â°C. The currently inadequate service, with intermittent flows and pressures, would be improved under the proposed project. Details of the UB water supply system are given in Annex 1. 2.13 Reservoirs. The existing reservoir system is both underutilized (by half of its capacity) and unintegrated, to the detriment of water pressure in the system as well as service coverage. With three commissioned reservoirs (the Northwest, the "3/4 district" and the Tasgan) in the hills north and east of UB not linked to each other, and two completed reservoirs (the Northwest and the "X") not yet commissioned, system capacity is far from being fully utilized to provide adequate system storage or gravity system pressure. And none of the reservoirs, except the easternmost, are high enough to service by gravity the large ger population in a large valley north of UB. The project's general objectives are to assist the Government to: (a) address the inequity of services between ger and formal housing areas, thereby improving the quality of life of the low-income population; (b) restore levels and quality of water supply services in the Municipality and make that supply accessible to the ger areas; and (c) develop more efficient and autonomous, performance- oriented institutions, with a view to eventual privatization. The project design takes into consideration Ulaanbaatar's severe winter climate, which is comparable to that of Anchorage, Alaska. The main potential problem is freezing of water in pipework systems, particularly in ger areas where low flows can be expected with the low water demand. Frost penetration could exceed 5.5 meters in the city and 6 to 8 meters in northern exposed ger areas. However, a cost comparison indicates that it is more economical to insulate pipes and prevent stagnation than to lay small pipes below the frost penetration line. Specific design features were therefore adopted for the pipe insulation, pipe material, burial depth and coverage of pipelines and rises serving kiosks, flow patterns in distribution pipes and reservoirs, looped connections to water-delivering kiosks, minimization of dead-end pipes, introduction of special drainage, and control and maintenance features in case of system failures and need of pipe repairs. Specific investments such as a recirculating ger looped network and boiler r-calculation near and around reservoirs have been included in the project. OVERVIEW 6.1 The proposed project, with its focus on ger area upgrading, will help ease the social burden of structural reform and the country's transition to a market economy by improving urban services and hygiene in the ger areas. The project would provide piped water to about 169,000 people or 70 percent of the 12 ger areas supplied. About 75,000 of those beneficiaries would also gain other basic infrastructure under the project. Project support and service improvements to the existing system would benefit all those now served with a steadier supply at higher pressure. As the first IDA-supported urban development project in Mongolia, it also introduces market-oriented provision and management of urban services by providing an adequate cost recovery mechanism combined with financial incentives for water conservation and operational efficiency. Furthermore, an institutional development and reform action plan will reshape UB's water supply and sanitation utility to function in a market economy in a financially and environmentally equitable and sustainable manner. B. EcONOMIc ANALYSIS 6.2 The project comprises three major components: water supply for UB's ger areas, water supply to the central city area, and ger area upgrading. As each component has a different type of economic benefit, the analysis is carried out by component. Quantitative cost-benefit analysis, possible only for the two water supply components, focuses on the incremental costs and benefits between the "with project" and "without project" cases, based on the financial analysis. When necessary and appropriate, appropriate proxies and shadow prices are used to measure economic benefits and costs that differ from financial benefits and costs. Details of the economic analysis are given in Annex 14. Ger Area Water Supply 6.3 In the ger areas, the benefits and costs have been quantified to the extent possible. The major benefit is increased consumption of water to a level of 20 lcd, considered the minimum requirement for health and hygiene, at a much lower price than before. The economic benefit to ger residents is measured using the 1995 price of water as a proxy for consumers' willingness to pay. An additional benefit is derived from the savings in capital investments and recurrent costs to maintain a larger fleet of trucks and tanks, owing to the introduction of a piped water supply to cover 70 percent of the ger area population. This benefit is compared to the initial capital investment to provide water supply to kiosks under the project. The resulting economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is 19 percent. It should also be noted that the project's major benefits will accrue to ger residents whose average income is estimated to be 70 percent of apartment dwellers'
 - 47 - incomes, and who include the urban poor. The additional consumption of potable water will substantially enhance the level of health and hygiene in ger area, and easier access to kiosks will also decrease work for ger area women and children who traditionally haul water home. These qualitative benefits, albeit substantial, are not involved in the quantitative analysis. City Water Supply Improvements 6.4 In the central city water supply component, the benefits come from reduced consumption of valuable resources rather than from incremental benefits or production. In fact, the supply of water will decrease under the project. The "with project" case assumes that, with the introduction of block metering and step tariffs, the wastage of water will substantially decrease, requiring fewer resources to produce the water and collect, treat and discharge wastewater. The benefits of treating less wastewater and using fewer resources for water production are all captured as USAG handles both operations. The resultant EIRR of 14.4 percent, however, understates the real benefits, as the benefits of a more stable water supply with higher and more evenly distributed water pressure backed by reserve capacity in reservoirs are difficult to quantify and are therefore excluded from the analysis. Also omitted from the analysis is the unquantified benefit of the enhanced efficiency and accountability derived from institutional strengthening supported by project technical assistance. 6.5 The weighted average EIRR for the water supply component is estimated to be 15.9 percent, based on the above analysis. The real benefit of the proposed project would be much larger, however, owing to its significant unquantified benefits. The very concept of serving ger area residents equally with the apartment dwellers will also provide a basis for similar future interventions for other types of municipal service. Most of these benefits, though hard to quantify, are substantial and directly accrue to Ger residents. Provision of total length of 10.8 km roads, a bridge, and 30.8 km all-weather footpaths with four footbridges in areas with the most critical needs can help save substantial time for the residents to haul coal and wood, other household goods as well as to fetch water. For example, the maximum travel distance for 20 kg water fetching will be reduced from the maximum of 700 m to 350 m, and the footpaths will help ease the labor of water fetching usually carried out by women and children. The benefit from easier fuel hauling is no less significant, considering the bulky nature of coal and wood and its position as the second largest expenditure item in Ger area. The estimated time saved for water fetching alone would amount to over 10 million hours/year for 86,000 people, similar saving is expected coal, wood and other household supplies. Paved roads can also substantially save the fuel cost and maintenance expenditure for delivery trucks and other vehicles, as well as save the time for delivery. The economic rate of return for $1.4 million

Likewise, improvement in solid waste collection would improve the hygiene of Ger area considerably. Also important are the benefits from the construction of the stormwater drainage in flood-prone areas, which can help reduce the property damage as well as avoid the loss of human lives. In addition to these direct benefits, overall infrastructure improvements would motivate the voluntary investments for further improvements in each individual plot by each household. Prior to 1950, Ulaanbaatar (UB) had relatively few inhabitants who lived exclusively in gers and took their water from the Tuul River. But with significant population growth, the tanking of water became necessary in 1950, with deliveries made directly to family plots. Wells were also used but, by 1965, they were closed due to pollution and the system of water sales kiosks was established. 2. Also from about 1958, the construction of a piped water reticulation system was established in the city's formally developed area and that system has been extended and improved since then. The water supplied to the system is primarily from aquifers and is obtained from wellfields with numbers of boreholes, each with its submersible pump. Once lifted from the boreholes, the water is chlorinated before being pumped to supply. These networks directly supply the formally developed areas of the city, while the peri- urban areas still rely on the operation of a road tanker fleet that obtains most of its supply via filling stations connected to the water mains. 3. The present supply system suffers from aging assets, intermittent supplies and lack of pressure in the pipelines, with the consequent risk of contamination. WATER DEMAND 4. In 1995, water demand in UB totaled about 161,935 m3/d, of which 121,532 m3/d from apartments (296,420 persons at 410 lcd), 38,159 m3/d from industry, and 2.244 m3 /d from ger residents (224,443 persons at 10 lcd). UB's 74,000 apartments with hot and cold running water housed about 323,000 in 1995, of whom 296,420 were supplied from the municipal water supply network. WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM 5. Supply Sources. There are four existing water supply sources called the Upper, Central, Industrial and Meat Complex. They all extract groundwater from aquifers along the Tuul River. The groundwater source capacity has been investigated and found to have potential for future development. 6. Upper Source is located about 45 km upstream of UB. Water is collected from 39 wells, and intake pumps deliver it to 2/1,000 m3 storage reservoirs (Total Water Level, TWL, 1,425 m). The water is pumped over a ridge to the "X" reservoir (not yet commissioned) and the city. There are six pumps at the pump station, each with a nominal capacity of 1,000 m3/hr. The pipeline has a design capacity of 72,000 m3/d, but
 - 56- ANNEX I is currently delivering only 24,000 m3/d, with delivery pressure much less than expected. Only 1.2 pumps (operating 20 hr/d) are needed to deliver the current production, so there is potential to substantially increase output from the Upper Source. The majority of flow from the Upper Source pipeline is proposed to go to the Northeast Reservoir (2/6,000 m3 tanks with a TWL of 1,387 m), which is not yet in service. 7. Central Source is located on the Tuul River near the city center. Water is collected from 70 wells and delivered to 10,000 m3 reservoirs (6,000 m3, 3,000 m3, 2/500 mi3). Its design capacity is 97,000 m 3/d, and it is presently delivering about 90,000 m3/d to the city network. The main delivery pipeline comprises 3/600 mm diameter mild steel mains that direct flow into the network and toward the Tasgan Reservoir (3/6,000 m3 tanks) with a TWL of 11,335 m. 8. Industrial Source is located downstream of the Central Source and includes 16 wells with intake pumps that deliver to 2/2,000 mi3 storage reservoirs. The pump station contains four pumps with nominal capacities of 2/200 and 2/250 m3/hr. The delivery mains to the city network and industrial area are 500, 3/400 and 300 mm diameter mild steel mains. The design capacity is 43,000 m 3/day and it is now delivering about 22,000 m3/d, which means that all four pumps are operating 24 hr/d. 9. Meat Complex Source is located downstream of the Industrial source and includes 8 wells that deliver water to 2/2,000 mi3 storage. The pump station has four pumps with nominal capacities of 2/160 and 2/250 m3/hr. The delivery mains to the city network and meat processing area are 2,400 and 2/250 mm diameter mild steel mains that now deliver about 16,000 m'3/d of flow to the city. This flow will be directed to the Northwest reservoir (2/3,000 m3 tanks with TWL of 1,347 m) when it comes into service. All pumps are operating 20 hr/d, so there are no standby pumps. 10. Reservoirs: Utilization of Unused Capacity in the Proposed Project. There are five existing reservoirs in the system on the hills north and east of UB. They are not linked to each other, or fully utilized to provide adequate system storage or gravity system pressure. USAG and MUB have indicated the inadequate use of the reservoirs is due to inadequate information about their level of filling, and that a telemetric system would assist in an integrated use of all reservoirs. Nor, with the exception of the easternmost (Northeast) reservoir, are they high enough to service by gravity the large ger population in the large valley north of UB. To a large extent, pressure is maintained in the network by direct pumping from the well-head sources. However, many areas suffer from inadequate water supply and pressure, and facilities serving high-rise apartment blocks are not equipped to boost-pump water to the higher floors in nine-story buildings. 11. The total water storage volume available is 48,000 mi3, of which only 24,000 m 3 is currently used. Fifty percent of constructed service storage remains a dormant asset due to weak points (weak valves and pipe segments), particularly in the northeastern section of the deteriorated city network, which would not withstand the higher pressures caused by putting the reservoirs in service. While pipe segments are designed for working
 - 57 - ANNEX 1 pressure of 100 to 120 m, in practice they break at about 60 to 80 m head. The proposed project would therefore rehabilitate the transmission system and commission the reservoirs in order to increase pressure in the system, provide a continuous water supply and make more water available to users. 12. The "X" Reservoir. The unused "X" reservoir was constructed to operate as a break pressure tank to limit pressures into the city network, transmission system weaknesses delayed reservoir commission. The reservoir comprises 2/3,000 m3 tanks with TWL of 1,430 m. With the reservoir, the hydraulic head developed at the location where the main transmission main enters the city is around 1,385 m, whereas current pressures are about 1,350 m. With this available head, the pressures are enough to supply flows by gravity directly to the Northeast Reservoir, also now unused. This would allow the Northeast Reservoir, commanding pressures from an elevation of 1,382 m, to function as a supply reservoir for the Hailast Reservoir to be constructed under the proposed project. 13. "3/4" and Northeast Reservoirs. The "3/4" Reservoir would be mobilized to serve both as a supply reservoir for the immediate city network and to fill up the two adjacent lower reservoirs, the Northwestern and the Tasgan. As the highest of the three reservoirs, the "3/4" can also be used to supplement the other two reservoirs and thereby eliminate the need for the pumping now carried out from the Tasgan reservoir to the city network, as well as to fill the Northwest reservoir. A 500 mm diameter northern link would also provide additional filling capacity into the Northeast reservoir, for which supply would be to both the city network and to the ger reservoir at Hailast. 14. Northwestern Reservoir. The project's southern link pipeline will provide a direct connection to the Northwestern Reservoir from the upper source. 15. Raw Water Pipelines. There are about 98 km of unlined mild steel pipelines conveying the raw water from the well intake pumps to the source storages. 16. Water Quality. A JICA study indicates that the water generally complies with Mongolian and World Health Organization standards, although levels of chrome, manganese and fluoride occasionally exceed desirable levels in one of the aquifers close to the industrial zone. 17. Distribution System. Each of the four main water source works delivers water to its supply system. These systems are interconnected at strategic locations but do not incorporate either flow or pressure control. The pipes are of steel or cast iron and range in diameter from 100 mm to 800 mm. Generally, pipes are laid at a depth of 3 to 3.5 m. The system was built from 1958 to 1990 and extends some 240 km. 18. The delivery of water to the distribution networks is by pumping: first from the ground reservoirs at the source works and thereafter either from USAG's booster stations or from the Central Heating Point (CTP) stations or booster pumps at individual buildings. The supply of water therefore depends on the continued availability of
 - 58 - ANNEX I electrical power at various locations around the city, and since this is intermittent, so too is the availability of water. When power is off, the pressure in the water mains is lost and vacuum conditions develop, thus drawing in air to the pipework. Where the integrity of underground pipes is poor, this negative pressure can draw groundwater into the system, thereby creating contamination. 19. Except for sections supplied by the "Tasgan" and "3/4" reservoirs, the water supply network "floats" on the pumping plant that has to respond to diurnal changes in demand. This method of operations is inefficient and provides a poor level o f service. 20. Pipe Materials Used and Cold Climate Effects. Pipes are either steel or cast iron, with no internal lining or protection. The outside of some pipe is coated with bitumen or wrapped with asphalt sheets. Lack of internal protection leads to rust stains, one of the main causes of discoloration in the water supply. Trench depths are usually 2 to 3 m, and there appears to be a lack of control during installation of the trenching methods and provision of adequate bedding and compacting of materials. Pipe joints are generally caulked and without adequate maintenance may have deteriorated and be a major cause of the pipelines not withstanding high pressures. Pressure above about 60 to 80 m results in significant leakages into pipe and appurtenances. A common practice to prevent the pipelines from freezing is to install cold water pipes in the same trench as heating or hot water pipes, but this is limited to installations at and downstream of the CTPs.

 - 64 - ANNEX4 ANNEX 4: WATER SUPPLY METERING 1. It is Government policy to introduce metering and to support the principle of "user pays" pricing for all water and electricity consumers. A Government decree was passed in 1995 that stipulates that water and electricity meters would be installed in all individual premises by 1998. However, this involves a substantial financial commitment, and implementation of the policy has not yet commenced. Previous studies carried out in 1994/95 under the Ministry of Energy's responsibility, have highlighted the extent of water wastage and losses in apartment buildings, and the potential for substantial reductions in water supply operating costs if these losses can be eliminated. CURRENT SITUATION 2. Ulaanbaatar's water supply network was initially equipped with water meters at all distribution booster stations (CTP), which are located ahead of the secondary networks serving apartment networks; all wells and pumping stations were installed without any meter. Most of these meters have ceased functioning over time, and the water company, USAG, has found it impossible to determine overall production rates from the wells or amounts pumped in each of the CTPs for hot and cold water boosted to the block buildings of the apartments. 3. Downstream of the CTP and secondary networks, design of piping in apartments has generally included within each stairwell two cold water rising pipes and one hot water rising pipe. Except in the most recently constructed buildings, there is no returning hot water pipe. All networks downstream of a CTP are currently owned and maintained by the 17 subsidiaries of the Housing and Maintenance Service Company (OSNAAK). These 17 subsidiaries, named kantors, are physically responsible for at least one pumping station (CTP), a few small stocking reservoirs, the secondary networks and all plumbing facilities in the apartment buildings. 4. USAG remains responsible for direct water service to industries, institutional clients such as schools and hospitals and a very limited number of domestic customers in the center of the city. There are about 1,060 accounts directly managed by USAG. Although 100 of these accounts are metered and have operating meters, most of the billing has been carried out on the basis of norms established over time based on Soviet standards and applied for both design and billing of consumers. USAG bills the CTPs on the basis of a domestic water consumption of 150 liters per capita per day, whereas recent water consumption surveys have demonstrated that apartment inhabitants can consume as much as 410 lcd. 5. The current situation of water losses in the primary distribution system owned and maintained by USAG remains very unclear as no survey of water losses has been carried
 - 65 - ANNEX4 out; USAG indicates that water breakages on these primary mains occur about 20 to 30 times per year. Water losses and wastage are far higher in secondary networks and apartment plumbing fixtures. The kantors do not keep records of the number of pipe breakages on the secondary network, but their managers state that the number of plumbers within each kantor (one person per 1,200 to 2,000 apartments) is insufficient to face demands caused by leaks on secondary networks, block apartment buildings and internal apartment properties. A survey conducted in 1994 with the introduction of experimental metering in two apartment buildings demonstrated that: (a) initially, water consumption was at about 310 to 330 lcd; (b) after undertaking a fixture replacement program on one building and setting individual meters on each apartment pipe riser, water consumption dropped to about 163 lcd, while it remained at about 240 lcd without any fixture repair program; (c) apartment inhabitants were highly conscious of the need to conserve water by closing water taps whenever repaired, and sensitive to the introduction of water billing based on actual consumption and had started requesting more frequent plumbing assistance from kantor staff to maintain as low a water wastage as possible. The survey also pointed out that the pattern of consumption also changed, with metered apartments using much less cold water in total and percentage terms. STRATEGY AND PROPOSALS 6. In view of the extreme difficulty of obtaining reliable data to rationalize water utilization and develop a satisfactory billing system, Mongolia's professional community has recognized the need to urgently reintroduce metering and provide incentives to the population to control the water wastage occurring either through abusive use of both hot and cold water or leaking faucets and apartment fixtures and the deteriorating stock of leaky pipes outside apartment properties. A first effort is under way under a preliminary JICA-financed initiative focusing on the study and strengthening of UB's water production assets. The JICA funding would include provision of water meters to monitor water production by the pumping stations and installation of about 51 water meters at the 37 CTPs. This program would be completed before the end of 1997. JICA also intends to fund the metering and automation of pumping stations of all production facilities over the next few years. 7. Three options for apartment metering have been considered: (a) metering individual apartments; (b) metering building cores (i.e., typically groups of 12 to 27 apartments); or (c) metering buildings separately (i.e., groups of more than 60 apartments). Cost estimates are, respectively, $7.7 million, $1.2 million and $0.6 million. It is recognized that metering individual apartments may be adopted because it is most socially equitable, and metering buildings separately is the least expensive and equitable and would be the least likely to achieve significant water conservation. However, the proposed option, metering building cores, is a compromise because of its acceptable cost to the community and because it can commence the process of linking responsibility for water consumption with the cost of water to apartment residents. It also follows logically from the CTPs' metering and is a timely step in the process of introducing volume-based charging.

The apartment housing estates are clustered near the city center or along the main roads of UB and are relatively well-served by public transport-the favored mode up to 1990. UB's housing future for the majority of the population appears to lie in Ger area development. 68. The existing Ger area are mostly on the outlying hills and valleys to the north, northwest and northeast of UB and 2-12 kilometers from UB's economic activity. 69. Families interested in obtaining a Ger plot apply to local Khoroo offices (city subdistricts, the smallest unit of city administration). Plots of 300-500 m are located and staked out by a city surveyor. Most new residents obtain plots this way, although there is an increasingly active city real estate market. Only 10 percent of the plots are estimated to be occupied by unregistered settlers. 70. As all land was owned by government and the semidesert land is open, uncultivated, though hilly and sometimes deeply-ravined, it is amenable to rapid Ger development with few legal or natural constraints-except for water supply and possibly heating fuel. 71. Ger are laid out in simple, relatively long and narrow, rectilinear plots with long, wide public rights-of-way between rows of plots. Plot-holders construct wooden fences around their plots and have constructed a mixture of Ger (a circular, demountable wooden tent with a felt and canvas cover), wooden frame and masonry structures. Because of large plot sizes and the configuration of the infrastructure, Ger densities of 110/ha (with extremes of 45 and 200 in the selected areas) are quite low.  -121- ANNEX 12 ANNEX 12: FINANCIAL ANALYSIS OF ULAANBAATAR MUNICIPALITY OVERVIEW 1. Ulaanbaatar, with more than 25 percent of Mongolia's total population, had an operating budget of Tug 23.9 billion in 1995, equivalent to 18 percent of the national budget of Tug 131.3 billion. Due to the economic upheaval of the early 1990s, the budget of the Municipality of Ulaanbaatar (MUB) shrank dramatically in 1992 and then stabilized in real terms ever since then as did its size relative to the national budget. The MUB budget is divided into the current budget for operating expenditures and the capital budget for new investments. MUB has no outstanding debts and its revenues have grown in line with inflation since 1992. The expected introduction of a property tax on the recently privatized apartments and MUB's policy of increasing tariffs for urban services to recover operating costs will help further consolidate its finances. 2. The proposed IDA credit will be directly onlent from the central government to USAG. MUB, however, agreed to provide $1.26 million as counterpart funding and had already earmarked Tug 200 million in the 1997 budget as part of the project's counterpart funding to carry out the construction of two connecting pipelines to support the project. The project will not create any excessive burden on MUB as IDA's credit will be paid back by the expected revenues of USAG. 3. The AusAID grant of $5 million will be passed on to the municipality. The investments supported by AusAID for the next five years amounts to 50 percent of MUB's 1996 capital budget and will substantially help relieve the burden of municipal finance. The AusAID component will relieve some of MUB's financial burden for ger investments by introducing the concept of cost recovery and establishing a Ger Infrastructure Development Fund. PAST PERFORMANCE 4. The operating budget accounts for around 75 percent of the total budget. Taxes are the major source of operating budget, accounting for around 80 percent. The business income tax is the largest source but with declining shares at over 40 percent currently, followed by the trade tax and personal income tax with 14 and 12 percent, respectively. On the expenditure side, the personnel cost, including a social security contribution, is the largest cost, with its share increasing from 30 percent in 1994 to 48 percent in 1996. By sector, education and health accounts for 80 percent of total expenditure. Except in 1995, the operating budget has recorded small annual surpluses, which were used as a source for the capital budget in the following year.
 -122 - ANNEX 12 5. The capital budget as a proportion of the operating budget was as high as 50 percent in 1991 when subsidies from the central government were large. Since then, its size relative to the operating budget has been stable at around 25 percent. Its source includes the carryover surplus from the current budget, and revenues from special funds such as the housing sales fund, road fund, and fixed asset sales and leases. An additional source is the subsidy from the central government. One major source of the central government subsidy, the apartment construction fund provided by Russian aid, dropped dramatically in 1992 and was discontinued from 1994. 6. In constant terms, both the current and capital budgets shrank substantially in 1992, mainly due to an exchange rate adjustment and hyperinflation that began in 1991. The consequent reduction was more dramatic in the capital budget, which dropped to 14 percent in 1992 from the previous year in constant terms. As MUB did not adjust its urban services fees to catch up with inflation, it scaled down its operation and maintenance as well as new investments. This also brought about gradual deterioration of the quality of urban services. Even with these adjustments, however, many urban operations such as transportation, solid waste, and housing services resulted in losses, which were subsequently covered by subsidies from the central government. Realizing that this practice is not sustainable and results in waste and inefficiencies, the government allowed tariff increases to cover the operating cost of services from 1994. FUTURE DEVELOPMENT 7. Currently, MUB does not prepare a detailed medium-term budget projection. It hopes that it can meet the increasing demand for better urban services by various initiatives. It will continue to push for tariff increases for various urban services to recover the cost of services. It is also endeavoring to increase efficiency of service delivery by introducing competition and privatization where warranted. 8. One of the most important initiatives is the imminent housing privatization, which will also affect the municipal budget. The privatization of apartments will allow the Municipality to charge apartment residents fees that better reflect the cost of services. More importantly, however, this will provide a basis for charging the new owners with property taxes. The total value of apartments in MUB, with space totaling 22 million m2, is estimated at around Tug 330 billion. Although the timing, the tax rate as well as the allocation of tax revenue between the central and municipal government need to be decided in the future, the introduction of a property tax on privatized apartments will give the municipal budget a major boost. 9. MUB also recently launched the MUB Infrastructure Development Fund, initially funded by donations, and plans to expand the fund with various sources including auctioning off land tenures for buildings, charging immigration fees into MUB and other miscellaneous fees. To be more effective, this fund will require more sustainable funding sources.
 -123 - ANNEX 12 10. Despite the various initiatives already introduced, MUB realizes that it needs a more comprehensive and systematic approach to improve its municipal finance to meet the increasing and changing need for urban services and infrastructure in a transitional economy. It plans to carry out a study on municipal finance with the support of a bilateral donor. 11. MUB's cash flow projection, which includes the proposed project investment and debt services, is developed and attached. Even with conservative assumption of no property tax from apartments, it confirms the fact that MUB will not face cash flow problems as the cash inflow from USAG more than offsets its cash outflow to GOM. Moreover, actual revenues of MUB are expected to be greater, with the introduction of property tax on apartments.

 -132 - ANNEX 14 ANNEX 14: ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF THE PROJECT CHOICE OF SECTOR 1. The quality of urban services in Mongolia has deteriorated badly since the withdrawal of Soviet assistance in 1990 and the resulting economic crisis. Since 1990, most capital investment and expansion projects have been halted, and rehabilitation, even minor repairs of existing assets, has been severely curtailed. In general, the formal utility services face severe equipment problems. All equipment originated from FSU countries and is now difficult to replace or maintain with spares because of the severance of relationships with previous suppliers and inadequate hard currency to pay for imports. For instance, more than 10 percent of the wells in the well fields supplying Ulaanbaatar are inoperative due to faulty pumps; the municipal sewage plant treats only 75 percent of the sewage due to defective pumps and equipment; and pipe breaks take three to four days to repair due to lack of materials and equipment. 2. Low levels of cost recovery, typical of the Soviet era when users contributed little and utilities received substantial subsidies for new investments, have exacerbated service delivery problems. Metering-whether water, heat, or power-on apartment blocks or individual premises is almost nonexistent. Water and sewerage are billed on the basis of consumption norms, and collection of bills. While tariff levels cover full costs of the present low level of operations and depreciation, they would be insufficient to cover costs required to fund adequate levels of maintenance and rehabilitation, much less new investments in the systems. 3. In mid-1994, the Government's concern about the condition of Mongolia's cities, which had begun to show the effects of several years of forced neglect, caused it to request Association assistance in carrying out an informal review of urban services in Mongolia's main cities. In particular, urban issues were assessed from the perspective of two government goals: poverty alleviation and devolution of functions and responsibilities to local governments. The findings of the review were discussed at length with the Government, and the proposed project designed to meet the twin goals of poverty alleviation and improved sector efficiency. In preparing project assistance to the poor ger areas, a menu of possible improvements was discussed with representatives of the 12 ger communities, who were able to choose the specific types of investments most needed in their areas. Consultation with the representatives continued throughout preparation. The result is a project tailored to the needs of both the Municipality and the ger residents and strong ownership of the initiatives planned, and balanced with Mongolia's debt servicing capacity.
 -133 - ANNEX 14 4. Ger Infrastructure Improvements-Economic Evaluation. Planned Ger improvement covers various subcomponents reflecting the priorities of the Ger residents, generating various economic benefits. Most of these benefits, though hard to quantify, are substantial and directly accrue to Ger residents. Provision of total length of 10.8 km roads, a bridge, and 28.1 km all-weather footpaths with four footbridges in areas with the most critical needs can help save substantial time for the residents to haul coal and wood, other household goods, as well as to fetch water. For example, the maximum travel distance for 20 kg water fetching will be reduced from the maximum of 700 m to 350 m, and the footpaths will help ease the labor of water fetching usually carried out by women and children. The benefit from easier fuel hauling is no less significant, considering the bulky nature of coal and wood and its position as the second largest expenditure item in Ger areas. The estimated time saved or water fetching alone would amount to over 1O million hours/year for 86,000 people, and similar saving is expected for coal, wood and other household supplies. Paved roads can also substantially save the fuel cost and maintenance expenditure for delivery trucks and other vehicles, as well as save the time for delivery. The economic rate of return for $1.4 million investment for road construction is estimated to be over 40 percent. Construction and operation of public bathhouses and laundries can improve the health of Ger residents. Likewise, improvement in solid waste collection would improve the hygiene of Ger areas considerably. Equally important are the benefits from the construction of the stormwater drainage in flood-prone areas, which can help reduce the property damage as well as avoid the loss of human lives. In addition to these direct benefits, overall infrastructure improvements would motivate the voluntary investments for further improvements in each individual plot by each household. Some of these benefits would be captured by the increase in property prices, particularly in light of the forthcoming privatization of urban land. Poor families, in particular, are likely to aim to increase their income by renting space to other families. The large plots and low density of development in Ulaanbaatar ger area provide substantial scope for rental units. Because of the lack of a legal property market in UB, the rapidly-shifting effects of the transition from public to private ownership and from a managed to a market economy and the lack of data on land prices, the above-mentioned benefits from upgrading have not been quantified. The benefits captured in land prices change over time, also depend closely on the location of particular Ger areas in relation to city economic activity centers, transportation services and city economic growth. However, the experience with slum upgrading for low-income populations in other countries is that unit land prices experience a one-time increase of between 25 and 27 percent of preimprovement value, while the expenditure on investment in housing and related on-plot infrastructure, such as sanitation, jumps from a few percent of household income to as much as 30 percent or more of household income. OVERVIEW 5. The project comprises three major components: water supply in the Ger area, water supply in central city area, and Ger area upgrading. As each component's economic benefit has different features, the analysis is carried out by component.
 -134- ANNEX 14 WATER SUPPLY INVESTMENTS 6. In the Ger area, the benefits and costs are quantified to the extent possible. The major benefit is the increased consumption of water to the level of 20 lcd, which is considered the minimum requirement for health and hygiene. This benefit is measured using the 1995 price of water adjusted to the end-1996 price level as a proxy for consumers' willingness to pay. Additional benefits are derived from the reduction of capital investments to purchase tanks and trucks and recurrent costs to maintain a larger fleet of trucks as a result of piped water supply to kiosks to cover 70 percent of the Ger area population. The EIRR is estimated at 18 percent. It should be noted that the major benefits of the project, measured as a gap between willingness to pay and actual payment, will accrue to Ger residents. There are other substantial benefits, although difficult to quantify. The additional consumption of potable water will substantially enhance the level of hygiene in Ger areas, and project investments to facilitate access to the public water kiosks will also help relieve the labor burden of women and children, who are traditionally responsible for hauling water. 7. Benefit-cost analysis for water supply investments in the central city area compares the incremental costs and benefits of the "with project" and "without project" cases, using shadow prices to reflect economic costs to the country. Unlike traditional projects, the benefits come from the reduced consumption of valuable resources rather than from incremental benefits or production. In fact, the water production will decrease with the project. The "with project" case assumes that, with the introduction of block metering and step tariffs, the wastage of water will substantially decrease, requiring fewer resources capital investments to purchase tanks and trucks. The benefits of treating less wastewater as well as using fewer resources for water production are captured as USAG covers both operations. The resultant EIRR of 14 percent, however, underrepresented the benefits since the unquantifiable benefits of having a more stable water supply with higher water pressure backed up by reservoirs have been excluded from the analysis. Another major nonquantifiable benefit is the enhanced efficiency and accountability derived from institutional strengthening supported by project technical assistance. 8. The weighted average EIRR for the water supply components is estimated to be 15 percent, although this excludes the significant unquantifiable benefits of better maintenance and repair, which would reduce future capital investment requirements considerably, benefits of easier access to the piped water in Ger areas, and benefits from the institutional strengthening component such as improved management and strengthened accountability.  -140 - ANNEX 15 ANNEX 15: GER AREA UPGRADING AND COST RECOVERY BACKGROUND 1. Population. The total Ger population is estimated to be about 300,000 in 1996. Since 1991, it had been decreasing slightly, but recently started to slowly increase as apartment construction practically ceased. 2. About 45 percent of UB's population live in the Ger areas. The density of Ger areas is very low, varying from 54 persons/ha in Nisek to 198 persons/ha in Gandan in the flat, low-lying city center. A significant number of people keep animals on their plots and some have gardens. Except for deeply-ravined Shar Khad, the population in the flat areas to the east of the city in Bayanzurkh had been decreasing, but is likely to increase in the future. 3. The population forecasts suggest that the population of the Ger Areas could double by about 2012, if gers grow faster than the rest of the city. There appear to be few options to accommodate this increase in suitable (existing) areas, where infrastructure can be provided. 4. The three areas that topographically are most suited to accommodate the growth are the flat areas in Bayanzurkh, mentioned above, the Naddam celebration site near the airport to the southeast of the city and the central wellfield area, if other water sources can be identified. Each of these options poses planning and development difficulties and in order to assess these and any other options, further study is required. 5. Incomes. Ger household incomes (in 1995/96) were as low as Tug 15,000 ($25 equivalent), or a median income of about Tug 30,000 in 1995 and Tug 40,000 in 1996, respectively (or $55 and $60, respectively). A sample survey in 1996 indicated that average ger incomes were about Tug 60,000, if capital expenditures were included. Many of the Ger residents appear to be elderly pensioners, the unemployed or underemployed and single-parent female households, for whom in the absence of subsidized apartment housing, the Ger is an affordable housing solution. Solid information about apartment incomes is unavailable but it is probably safe to say that Ger incomes are about 70 percent of those of people in apartments. 6. Ger Locations. Most of the Gers-except for Yarmag and Nisek-are located on the north bank of the Tuul River, the city's public water source. With the exception of the Gandan area, the majority of Ger area is in the periphery of the city at a distance of 2 to 12 km from the built-up area of UB, which parallels the Tuul River (Table 1 below). Many of the Ger population live on the hills to the north of the city along the Selbe and Tolgoit River valleys, where the Ger population had been mostly increasing. These areas
 -141- ANNEX 15 are drained by natural ravines, which increasingly erode their banks, due to dumping of solid waste in them by Ger residents. The disruption of drainage channels combined with a lack of paved, stabilized or graded roads, limits access by water trucks, buses and other vehicles and also hampers residents' access to and transport from water kiosks, especially in winter.
