This form of settlement needs to be constrained by a combination of revisions in land use in the Master Plan (para. 10 below), land regulation and institutions, and arrangements to provide or withhold services (such as water supply). 9. Planning Considerations. Until recently, Ger areas were considered to be temporary until apartment accommodation was built. Occupants were only given a right to occupy by the Municipal Duuregs for an unspecified time and sometimes after occupation of sites had taken place. This weak, impermanent form of tenure, combined with generally low Ger incomes, inhibits investment in house construction.
 -142 - ANNEX 15 10. The current Master Plan was prepared in 1986, before the massive changes in Mongolia's political and economic situation forced the curtailment of the apartment building program. In the longer run, the inefficient current Ger layout in long lanes and large (400-700 m 2) plots, without reservations for community open space and facilities, will need to be redeveloped. The Master Plan needs to be revised to incorporate the current situation in which the majority of the Ger areas are likely to develop into permanent residential areas. Also, the form of tenure to be provided to Ger residents under the ongoing (in 1997) program to privatize housing and land should take into account, if possible, future needs to restructure the infrastructure and reassemble plots in a more efficient configuration, suitable for an urban environment. 11. Water Supply. Since the 1960s, truck tanker water supply replaced wells or horse-borne transport; and in the 1970s water-dispensing kiosks were introduced. But the service is unreliable. 12. Water is usually fetched from kiosks to homes, in small-wheeled handcarts, loaded with up to 40 kg of water, over a distance of 200-700 m, mostly by women and children, over rough hilly, unstable and unsurfaced earth paths and roads. In the winter, ice and snow impede access to the kiosks by both tanker trucks and ger residents and water supply is erratic. Ger consumption from kiosks is about 8 lcd; the amount is limited by both cost and the difficulty of transporting the water and is well below the minimum requirement for good health and sanitation of 20 lcd. The total water consumed in Ger areas, although probably underestimated by USAG, is only 2.2 million m3/day, not even 2 percent of USAG's daily demand. 13. The high costs of tankered water have been inequitably passed through to Ger residents; they pay 20-30 times more per unit of water than apartment residents, whose costs are subsidized by institutional water consumers (industrial, commercial and public premises). Because of the high price of water and the difficulties in transporting it from kiosks to homes, many Ger residents supplement their water supply from other, sometimes unsanitary sources: rivers, surface water, wells and rainwater. During project preparation, the Municipality of Ulaanbaatar (MUB) recognized the inequity of Ger and apartment water charges and held ger unit charges constant while increasing apartment charges by over 50 percent. 14. The principal thrust of the project is to replace high-cost tankered water with much lower-priced and better-quality water, more consistently available, from the piped system. Standards and designs for the project water supply component are discussed in Annexes 1. 2 and 4. 15. Health and Sanitation. The inequity in and inadequacy of public services (lack of adequate heating, water, sanitation and social facilities) compounded by low incomes leads to significant nutritional, as well as morbidity and health differences, between Ger and apartment areas. A UNICEF nutrition survey of 1993 found that infants born into ger area families had a 60 percent higher risk of low weight than those born in apartments.
 -143 - ANNEX 15 Also, at least 80 percent of children in the Ger who are under five years old suffer from diarrhea in summer and acute respiratory infections in winter. (The equivalent percentages of children in apartments are less than 30 and 40 percent, respectively.) Upgrading of public services and living conditions in Ger area under the project, particularly water supply, would help relieve the hardships of the urban poor while improving environmental conditions with attendant health benefits. 16. There were bathhouses and washing facilities in the Ger. However, these were privatized in the first half of the 1990s; the prices set by MUB proved to be uneconomic and by 1996 only a few were still operating. Many Ger residents are said, perforce, to bathe in their relatives' apartments. Surveys indicate that lack of bathhouses is regarded as a major problem by Ger residents. 17. The project would provide the following bathhouse and laundry facilities in project ger areas: (a) Hailast. Improvement of existing facilities and addition of laundries; (b) Denjin and Chingeltei. A new bathhouse including laundry facilities; (c) Dambadarjaa. A new bathhouse including laundry facilities, and; (d) Gandan. Installation of a laundry facility 18. Most Ger plots have simple pit latrines for human waste disposal. Due to the low, but increasing densities in Ger and the nature of soils, the existing sanitation methods, though crude, are not a major problem, except possibly in the low-lying Ger area near the floodplain of the Tuul River. 19. Roads and Paths. In the Ger area roads and paths are almost entirely rough earth unconsolidated, poorly bridged and undrained. In the deeply ravined Ger area, access for vehicles of all types and pedestrians is difficult. The lack of storm drainage channels, the alignment of roads, often parallel to slopes, and lack of maintenance all impede and increase the costs of access for buses, trucks and other vehicles. In addition, the terraces of plots and access paths to them can be extremely long (up to 600 m of continuous frontage). 20. Criteria for Roads and Paths. The system has deteriorated due to lack of funds for operations and is now irregular from identifiable but uncontrolled points that are a maximum of 500 m from houses. Consequently, residents commonly dump their waste in drainage channels and natural ravines. Drainage capacity, thus, has been substantially reduced, causing local flooding and property damage sometimes. Project Standards and Criteria for Solid Waste 24. To alleviate these problems, it was considered that under the project the criteria should be that: the maximum distance that residents should be required to carry their solid waste should be limited; and the locations of solid waste collection points needed to be adjacent to suitable access roads, which in the cases of deeply ravined and floodplain areas would be have to be paved if the service was to function in all weathers. 25. From studies of the solid waste collection service, it also became apparent that significant improvements to the service and costs could be recovered if larger collection trucks were employed with compactor equipment. The project therefore aims to supplement the pedestrian-access standard and introduce a vehicular access standard such that: (a) No resident should need to carry their solid waste more than 200 m to an authorized collection point. (b) All-weather roads would be proposed to facilitate collection by larger collection vehicles. (c) The distances should be actual and not "as-the-crow-flies." 26. A standard of 5.5 m for road pavement width was adopted to allow two-way working of solid waste trucks and buses within the low trafficked areas. 27. The width of 1.2 m for footpaths was adopted to allow handcarts to pass; however, it is acknowledged that for much of the year it is possible to pass on the adjacent surface and, therefore, the edge treatment of paths requires attention to detail. Road and pedestrian bridges would be consistent with these standards. Stormwater Drainage 28. Ulaanbaatar is mainly drained by three rivers flowing from north to south into the Tuul River, which runs east to west. These rivers are from east to west: Uliastai, Selbe, Tolgoit and Naragiin. Their tributaries include the Chingeltei, Hailast and
 -146- ANNEX 15 Denjinmiyanga, which drain to the Selbe. Most of the drainage in the Ger area feeds into the north-south rivers: Uliastai, Selbe, Tolgoit. Over the long term, the annual volume of rainwater has been increasing and with it in recent years, flooding (in 1966, 1982 and 1994), a rise in the groundwater level and ground heave in expanding permafrost areas. 29. A fundamental storm drainage problem is that Ger Khoroos have developed over areas that are either steep-sloping or are adjacent to hills and are subject to seasonal storm runoff. Ger areas also straddle the natural drainage routes to the river Tuul, as do formal developments and the city center, which have been developed across the natural route of the river Selbe. 30. In addition, many of the tertiary channels have been filled with solid waste over many years and while they may retain their drainage function, local flooding is caused during the heaviest rainfall. On the other hand, in the absence of bridges, the deposits of waste assist in providing access across the deeply ravined areas during the remainder of the year. 31. Another major problem is created by mudflows from the streams flowing to the rivers Uliastai, Selbe, Tolgoit, and Naragiin. Mud and the larger shingle transported by the main rivers themselves, restricts flow in the main drainage channels. However, no regular attempt appears to be made to ensure that all the channels are clear and free of solid waste. This is particularly so at culverts under roads that sometimes also suffer from having less capacity than upstream channels. 32. In the Denjin ger area, for example, there is are no formal stormwater drainage provisions, while there are over 12 stormwater gullies and ravines with a total length of 9,000 m (lengths range from 120 m to 2,000 m). In winter, springwater charges freeze, affecting 30-40 households. In summer, flooding results in human casualties and property damage. 33. The lack of maintenance of the piped stormwater system in the city is evident during heavy storms as runoff is not accepted by the road gullies. Possibly many missing gully covers were removed and traded as scrap metal; and many have been officially removed and stored as a precaution against theft. All of this necessitates the regular cleaning and emptying of each gully, for which there is no special equipment and, consequently, the gullies are frequently full of debris. 34. MUB had developed a program to alleviate flooding-in Ger and regular areas of the city-as the drainage solutions are necessarily linked-and to reduce the rising groundwater and permafrost expansion. These phenomena have been studied in detail by MUB's Water Policy Unit (WPU). The WPU's main recommendation was to introduce a system of horizontal and vertical ground drainage in Sukhbaatar (100 ail) to the north of the city center. 35. Following serious flooding in 1966, 1982 and 1994 in the north of the city, MUB prepared an urgent program of works to prevent further damage. Without detailed
 -147 - ANNEX 15 assessment it would be unwise to draw firm conclusions on the effectiveness of these investments; however, inspection suggests that finding has sometimes dictated the extent and dimensions of the sections used and these may be inadequate and inconsistent in some locations. 36. In Naran, for example, which is close to the city, an extensive cutoff drain was built to protect Ger and the apartments below them, which can be densified-possibly with apartments. But, the area above the channel and the apartments continues to develop in Ger and is not protected from hillside runoff. 37. Nevertheless, the incidences of serious flooding appear to have been reduced by the works that have been completed and flooding continues to be concentrated in those areas where projects have been identified but not yet implemented. In the UB Ger areas, housing is a mixture of many uninsulated, small wooden buildings, a few brick or stucco buildings, with tarpaper roofs laid on boards, and "Ger." The centuries-old Mongolian "Ger" is basically a cheap (about $600 in 1996) one-room, circular (4-7 m diameter), mushroom-shaped, demountable tent, with transportable wooden frames and a thick felt and canvas covering, with substantial insulation but short heat retention value. doc.abstracts: The general objectives of the Ulaanbaatar Services Improvement Project are to assist the Government to: (i) address the inequity of services between ger and formal housing areas, thereby improving the quality of life of the low-income population; (ii) restore levels and quality of water supply services in the Municipality and make that supply accessible to the ger areas; and (iii) develop more efficient and autonomous, performance-oriented institutions, with a view to eventual privatization. Project's specific objectives are to: (i) improve the quality, quantity and reliability of water supply; (ii) substantially lower the unit cost of water supply to ger areas; (iii) improve ger area infrastructure; (iv) arrest the deterioration in, and improve the reliability and quality of, the city water distribution system; (v) reduce water wastage, the production of nonrevenue-producing water, and water production costs; (vi) replace the current norm-based water and sanitation billing system to one that is quantity-based; and (vii) develop the water and sanitation company of Ulaanbaatar's (USAG's) capabilities for financial and operational management and convert it into a self-financing commercially-oriented public utility. The project will include: 1) physical investments such as strengthening of water supply distribution network, concrete reservoirs construction, insulated pipelines, water leakage and wastage reduction program, equipment and tools for maintenance and meter repair workshops, sewer observation and cleaning equipment, and Ger Area Infrastructure Upgrading Program; and 2) institutional component consisting of technical assistance in project management, institutional strengthening of USAG, studies reviewing the long-term development and planning of ger areas and definition of appropriate levels of public services, and development of and training in a computerized USAG billing and collection system for metered supplies.
